title: Afterpay shares surge on Goldman upgrade
text:
Goldman Sachs Ashwini Chandra and Grace Fulton said they no longer apply a price to earnings multiple as its primary valuation method and have shifted to using weighting towards a Lifetime Value analysis which assumes the company may capture up to 25 per cent of the millennial market and will expand into new geographies.

The valuation also takes into account the potential that Afterpay could be acquired, pinning its M &A valuation at $47.

Goldman says an expansion into in-store US footwear and apparel and in-store health and beauty meant it was targeting an addressable market of $1 trillion.

Afterpay shares were further boosted by an update on the external audit into the company's anti money laundering processes.

In a statement released to the ASX on Wednesday, Afterpay said that the confidential interim report by external auditor Neil Jeans had been delivered to Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) .

It said the interim report did not contain recommendations "which will be left to the final report," due in 60 days.

Afterpay was forced to appoint an external auditor by the financial intelligence agency in June after issues were raised about its compliance with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws.

AUSTRAC said the decision to "release the report publicly is a matter for Afterpay" and that it "recognises that the audit is ongoing with significant work still to be undertaken."

"AUSTRAC will use the final audit report to determine the extent of any compliance issues and whether further regulatory action concerning Afterpay is required."

"As previously stated, Afterpay has not identified any money laundering or terrorism financing activity via our systems to date," Afterpay said on Wednesday.

"Afterpay’s systems include several features that help to control our money laundering and terrorism financing risk, including the implementation of strict spending limits.".

It said its systems did not allow for international transfers and that the payments on the platform were of small value, at $150 on average.

The report must contain details of any anti-money laundering provisions and rules that the auditor concludes Afterpay has not or is not complying with, and the facts relied upon by the auditor.

The probe came days after the company raised fresh capital from investors, sparking a disclosure controversy.

Last July, Afterpay said it had implemented an external identity verification process in partnership with data analytics company Illion to strengthen "fraud prevention" and to "help to ensure that everyone who uses Afterpay is over 18 years old".

Afterpay said at the time: "The ID verification process has been designed to minimise customer impact and is largely automated and instantaneous for the majority of customers".
description: The shares climbed by more than 13 per cent after Goldman Sachs lifted its price target on the buy-now pay-later juggernaut's stock to $42.90.
